content.title: Colonoscopy Procedure
content.summary: Colonoscopy is the gold standard for colorectal cancer screening and diagnosis of colonic pathology. It involves endoscopic visualization of the entire colon after adequate bowel preparation. Quality indicators include cecal intubation rate, adenoma detection rate (ADR), and withdrawal time. Polypectomy during colonoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
key_points: Gold standard for colorectal cancer (CRC) screening; recommended starting age 45
Adequate bowel prep is essential for quality colonoscopy
Adenoma detection rate (ADR) is the key quality indicator: ≥25% overall (≥30% men, ≥20% women)
Withdrawal time ≥6 minutes improves adenoma detection
Polypectomy: cold snare for <10mm, hot snare for ≥10mm polyps
Post-polypectomy surveillance intervals based on polyp number, size, and histology
content.statement: Colonoscopy is the gold standard for colorectal cancer screening and polyp removal, with quality measured by adenoma detection rate, cecal intubation rate, and adherence to surveillance guidelines.

explanation.intuition: Colonoscopy is like exploring a tunnel with a camera, looking for bumps (polyps) that could become cancer. The key is preparation (the tunnel needs to be clean to see everything) and thoroughness (taking time to look carefully). Finding and removing polyps during the procedure prevents cancer from developing.
explanation.key_insight: The adenoma detection rate (ADR) is the most important quality metric because it directly correlates with cancer prevention. Each 1% increase in ADR correlates with 3% decrease in interval CRC. Endoscopists with higher ADR catch more cancer precursors.
explanation.technical_details: Split-dose bowel prep (half the evening before, half morning of) yields superior cleanliness. Cecal intubation should be documented with photos of landmarks (appendiceal orifice, ileocecal valve, terminal ileum). Withdrawal time of ≥6 minutes (not including biopsy/polypectomy time) is associated with higher ADR.

definitions_glossary.colonoscopy: Endoscopic examination of the entire colon and terminal ileum
definitions_glossary.adenoma: Precancerous polyp (tubular, tubulovillous, or villous histology)
definitions_glossary.ADR: Adenoma detection rate; percentage of screening colonoscopies with ≥1 adenoma
definitions_glossary.cecal_intubation: Passage of colonoscope to the cecum (base of ascending colon)
definitions_glossary.bowel_preparation: Laxative regimen to cleanse colon for visualization
definitions_glossary.split_dose_prep: Half evening before, half morning of procedure; optimal prep
definitions_glossary.polyp: Growth projecting from mucosal surface; may be adenomatous or hyperplastic
definitions_glossary.cold_snare: Snare removal without cautery; for polyps <10mm
definitions_glossary.sessile_serrated_lesion: SSL; flat, subtle precancerous lesion in proximal colon
definitions_glossary.withdrawal_time: Time from cecum to anus during scope withdrawal; ≥6 min recommended

pathophysiology.mechanism: Visual inspection and therapeutic intervention in the colon

screening.average_risk: Starting age 45 (USPSTF 2021); repeat every 10 years if normal
screening.high_risk: Family history of CRC, personal history of polyps, IBD

diagnostic: Hematochezia or melena with negative upper endoscopy

bowel_preparation.split_dose: Half evening before, half morning of (4-5 hours before)
bowel_preparation.quality_scales: Boston Bowel Prep Scale; ≥6 overall (≥2 each segment)

medication_management.anticoagulation: Risk stratify procedure vs bleeding risk
medication_management.diabetes: Hold morning insulin/oral agents; monitor glucose

procedural_technique.insertion: Sequential advancement through rectum → sigmoid → descending → transverse → ascending → cecum
procedural_technique.cecal_landmarks: Appendiceal orifice, ileocecal valve; photograph for documentation
procedural_technique.terminal_ileum: Attempt intubation especially if right colon pathology suspected
procedural_technique.withdrawal: ≥6 minutes for careful inspection; technique matters

differential_diagnosis: Alternative screening: FIT, Cologuard (stool tests), CT colonography, sigmoidoscopy
Capsule colonoscopy for patients unable to complete standard colonoscopy

ESD.indication: Large sessile polyps >20mm for en-bloc resection

post_procedure.immediate_care: Monitor in recovery; assess for complications

complications.post_polypectomy_syndrome: Transmural burn without perforation; presents as localized pain, fever, leukocytosis

surveillance_intervals.SSLs: 3-5 years depending on size and dysplasia

definition.@value: Endoscopic examination of the entire colon for screening, diagnosis, and therapeutic removal of polyps

scopeNote.@value: Covers indications, bowel preparation, quality metrics, polypectomy techniques, and surveillance intervals

learning_objectives: List indications for screening vs diagnostic colonoscopy
Identify key quality indicators (ADR, cecal intubation, withdrawal time)
Select appropriate polypectomy technique based on polyp size
Determine surveillance intervals based on polyp findings
clinical_pearls: ADR is THE most important quality metric - higher ADR = less interval CRC
Split-dose prep is superior to evening-before-only prep
Cold snare for polyps <10mm; hot snare for ≥10mm
Photo-document cecal landmarks (appendiceal orifice, ileocecal valve)
High-risk adenomas (≥10mm, villous, HGD, ≥3 adenomas) = 3-year surveillance
common_misconceptions: Any bowel prep is equal - split-dose is superior
Speed doesn't matter - withdrawal time ≥6 min improves ADR
All polyps need hot snare - cold snare is preferred for <10mm
